thread.title: Equifax lobs informal bid for Veda Group, valuing it at more than $2.2 billion
thread.title_full: Equifax lobs informal bid for Veda Group, valuing it at more than $2.2 billion

author: Shaun Drummond and Jake Mitchell
title: Equifax lobs informal bid for Veda Group, valuing it at more than $2.2 billion
text:
Veda CEO Nerida Caesar last month. Her company says: "The board of directors of Veda intends to evaluate the expression of interest and will update its shareholders and the market in due course." Photo: Jessica Hromas
US-listed global credit bureau Equifax has lobbed a verbal bid for Veda Group at $2.70 a share, valuing the company at more than $2.2 billion.
Veda, a $1.7 billion data analytics business, which listed in December 2013 with a $1.5 billion market capitalisation, said there was no guarantee the offer, which was a 35 per cent premium to its present $2 share price, would lead to a formal bid and the board was now considering the offer.
Veda went into a trading halt at 10.33am on Friday morning which was to last until Tuesday. But it was lifted by 12.02pm when it confirmed the bid, as reported by Street Talk .
"The proposal is subject to a number of conditions including due diligence and regulatory approvals, which includes FIRB approval," the company said in a statement.
Advertisement "The board of directors of Veda intends to evaluate the expression of interest and will update its shareholders and the market in due course."
Macquarie Capital and law firm Herbert Smith Freehills are advising Veda on the offer.
Equifax, which has a market capitalisation of $US11.63 billion ($16.8 billion), is being advised by UBS.
Equifax is one of the three largest credit bureaus in the world, alongside Experian, which already competes with Veda in Australia and Trans Union.
This week, Veda scotched a rumour that it was going to buy iSentia.
More to come
